div.head: H. Buxton Forman (1842–1917)
div.p: Forman is now recognized as the equally active, if more shadowy, partner of the most notorious of late nineteenth‐century forgers, Thomas J. Wise. Their activities are largely discussed in the main note on forgery and, in greater detail, in the publication histories for Leoni and Scythian Guest. In the present note, some biographical details relevant to Ruskin scholarship is discussed; for more extensive biography, readers should consult Collins, Two Forgers.

Partingtonʼs popular expos√©, like Carter and Pollardʼs scientific one, was focused on Wise, but the forgeries gradually came to be understood as the products of a partnership between Wise and Harry Buxton Forman. Partington was reluctant to accuse Forman in the 1939 biography of Wise, Forging Ahead (e.g., 74–76, 158); and he wrote even more defensively on Formanʼs behalf in the 1946 revised version of the biography, Thomas J. Wise in the Original Cloth (84–92), by which time various conspiracy theories were afloat. More recently, Nicolas Barker and John Collins have extended the arguments of Carter and Pollard and established both Formanʼs complicity and a more extensive series of crimes than formerly suspected. Respecting Formanʼs involvement, Barker and Collins “conclude . . . that the partnership was an equal one. One partner might originate, manufacture and distribute one title more than another, even to all appearances exclusively; but the weight of the evidence suggests that the vast majority of the pamphlets were jointly manufactured and may be presumed to have been sold for joint profit” (A Sequel, 181). Nonetheless, a useful inquiry remains, which may require separating the forgers, respecting their motives and methods in faking Ruskin publications.

Another question concerns the extent and nature of the crime. In terms of simple numbers of forgeries, whereas Carter and Pollard were able definitively to condemn thirty of the nineteenth‐century pamphlets they examined, Barker and Collins have raised the tally to nearly a hundred. This more than tripled effort that the forgers are now known to have devoted to manufacture and dissemination of the fakes bears on the question of motive, which can now be understood more clearly in terms of crude gain (see Barker and Collins, A Sequel, 122). Interestingly, however, Barker and Collins also pursue the nature of the crime itself into “a range of activities that also included piracy and the adaptation of legitimate publications in a number of ways, whose object was to deceive the collector of modern writers (and also to cheat the author)” (A Sequel, 121). This complexity affects how the crime is perceived.
